Description: Body sherd of Chian Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black with part of lotus flower in added white outline and trace of added red centre; below, added red band lined in white; exterior: painted decoration on glazed black background consisting of female figure to left (red tress and white chiton with red spotted border remaining); at right, trace of undetermined white motif.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos describes this sherd as having been produced using the light and dark technique. The vase was first slipped white, then black followed by painted decoration using added red and added white. Whilst the technique is commonly found on the interior of Chian open vessels, it is not frequently found on the exterior surface of vases. Thus this sherd stands out as one of a small number of Grand Style vases created using the light and dark technique.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 285, no. 812, pl. 114)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 82, no. 17, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0857) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
